159292746.review:
[h1]I wanted to like this game, I really did[/h1]

I grinded my way through Runescape, WoW, Rust, and even EVE Online, so it's not like obscure mechanics or hardcore PvP were going to sour my experience. What it felt like with Myth of Empires was that it [b]actively fought against me every time I tried to have fun[/b].

First of all, let me say that my experiences here are from a PvP server perspective. If you plan on playing PvE only, STOP and go buy literally any other survival builder that has a foreign language localization that wasn't done by some shoddy outdated version of Baidu Translate. Nothing in this game makes sense when you try to read it because it's as if the devs are trying to discourage English speakers from playing (or French, or literally any other language setting except Chinese, and even then the item descriptions and dialogue feel like they were written by a 12 year old).

The key problem is that if your skills are low, you are [b]literally[/b] useless. As soon as you have your first PvP encounter, it is abundantly clear that the only way to not die in one shot, or to do any appreciable damage to your opponent, you need to either no-life this game for 20 hours a day, or resort to some stupid kind of borderline exploit. This means that, in order to be able to play the game, you have to NOT play the game (the actual fun bits, anyway). Here are some ACTUAL examples:

[u]Level too low?[/u] Make a bunch of stone sickles and go cut grass for a few hours until you level up. If this sounds mind-numbingly boring, it's because it is.

[u]Taking too much damage?[/u] Trap a bunch of foxes into a building with a respawn point, punch one of them on its stupid fuzzy jaw, and let them slowly nibble your ankles to death. Respawn and repeat for a few hours until you level up your health enough. If this sounds absolutely stupid, it's because it is.

[u]Not dealing enough damage?[/u] Clip a bunch of torture racks together and tie NPCs to them. Slap them with a rake for a few hours until your weapon skill is high enough. If this sounds eye-wateringly tedious, it's because it is.

After all that nonsense (which can take literally days), maybe you're ready to [b]actually play this game[/b]! Go fight some nerds alongside your guildmates! You gear up, run to a battleground, and start smacking them in the head with your spears. If you're winning, guess what happens? They will slap down a temporary structure with a respawn point, retreat their low health players back to this base, suicide, respawn, re-equip their gear, and get back into the fight in a matter of seconds with absolutely no penalty. If your group didn't think of this GENIUS strategy beforehand, well I guess f**k you!

So just avoid buying it to begin with, and save yourself a whole bunch of frustration.

162921268.review:
As much as it pains me to pen a negative review for a game that teeters on the brink of being a masterpiece, it’s necessary. This title, brimming with potential and ambition, could have been a landmark in its genre. However, despite the release, it is still a glorified playable alpha.

[b]Game mechanics[/b]
Gameplay mechanics themselves are innovative, incorporating elements that could set new standards for the genre. However, the lack of refinement is palpable. The combat system, which should be the game's crowning achievement, feels clunky and unfinished. Hit detection is inconsistent, and enemy AI is frustratingly unbalanced, making some sections of the game unnecessarily difficult while others are trivially easy.

[b]UI[/b]
The user interface, which should seamlessly integrate into the gameplay, is often obtrusive and unintuitive. Players will find themselves wrestling with poorly mapped controls and frequently navigating on overly-complex menu, which drastically disrupts the gaming experience.

[b]Translations[/b]
I have never seen such a terrible game translation in my life, expecially western non-english languages. Not even Google translate can do worst than this.

[b]Official servers[/b]
The lag is unreal, as unreal as the amount of Chinese zergs in every region (even locked ones) glitching, griefing and dishing out a surreal amount of racist insults. All this in the most total indifference of support and devs, who also have the tendency to ban people quite randomly.
Do you want to be toxic? Just be sure to write Chinese

[b]Game support[/b]
Additionally, a significant gripe that cannot be overlooked is the atrocious customer support, particularly for non-Chinese speaking players. The support system seems almost exclusively tailored for Chinese speakers, with little to no resources available for those who do not speak the language. Requests for assistance or bug reports submitted in English (or other languages) are met with delayed responses, or worse, no response at all. This lack of inclusivity not only alienates a large portion of the global gaming community but also exacerbates the frustration when dealing with the technical issues present in the game. It’s disheartening to see such neglect from the game’s support team, especially when the solution—a more robust and inclusive customer service framework—seems within easy reach.


This game could have been a monument to the art of video gaming, but without the necessary polish and bug fixes, it remains a monument to missed opportunities.

160012874.review:
Myth of Empires has nice features but ultimately the faults outweighed the positives.

Let's start with the positives:

Graphically, game looks nice and I liked the aesthetic
Placing building pieces starts them at low HP, so well thought out for pvp raids.
Cross server teleportation means there is always folks to fight
Something to fight for: taxing other players from their passive loot is a great system
Allowing players to set their own PvP raid protection times very nice
Base defense is great but limited to only small areas of the map

Now for the negatives:

Survival games are grindy, but this one takes it to another level (when players need to keep logged on with a jumping micro to level skills overnight, not a great sign)
Progression is expensive and to stay competitive real money needs to be spent on in game currency
The combat is not great or very skill oriented. I don't see how the directional combat adds much here and new skill abilities are locked to weapons and not characters
Very limited creatures to fight and the later versions are just higher level mobs already seen
Most in game items can be bought on the market with in game currency, including books to level up skills. This is really too close to the pay to win line for my taste

Here's to hoping the other survival games coming out in 2024 have more interesting gameplay and less pay to win aspects. Top on the list to try would be Soul Mask, V RIsing and Dune.

As for your feedback on the in-game currency and combat, I will forward that along to the devs. We will continue working on the game, and hopefully it will grow into something where you feel like the positives outweigh the negatives. 157307357.review:
I've got over 600 hours on this game. I'd start off by saying I've had a long break from games, for over a year now. Just lost that spark, hadn't found anything that kept me interested for longer than a week. When this game first came out on early access.. I instantly got sunk into it. ~300 hours, before the lawsuit came. I found out it was back two weeks ago, and put another ~250 hours since then (working from home). 

This game feels like a very modernized old-school RPG. Grind-intense, open-world, community-based, slow character progression, AFK skill grinding.. The vibes it brings are very much similar to something like Ultima Online, Everquest or RuneScape. If you've played those games and enjoyed them, you'd love this game, without a doubt. People who've enjoyed less grind-intense MMOs like World of Warcraft, or survival/building open world games like Rust, Ark, etc .. you'd most likely enjoy it as well. But you'd probably want to invite friends to play with you, or join someones guild in-game. This isn't meant for solo'ing, for the average player. If you intend on solo'ing this game .. intend on pouring dozens of hours per week to see any significant progress.

This game doesn't really start opening up with more avenues of game play until you start making decent progress into your character progression. At first the game is very slow, you'll still enjoy it since there's a pretty large learning curve that stays pretty intriguing all the way through. But it isn't until you establish a good base, tons of workbenches, decent amount of skill progression -- that you finally start being able to venture out into the harder parts of the map. At first, you'll die to about anything. Within about 20 hours you'll start handling just about anything in your starting area. Depending on your play style, character skills focus, guild population, etc.. you could be exploring deep across the massive map (emphasis on massive .. probably takes an hour+ to travel from one end to the other) within 100 hours. Or, if you're solo and focused a lot of crafting skills.. you could be waiting 300+ hours before you can venture that far out into the map. Your characters level doesn't mean much .. it's the skills you've leveled that determine your characters ability. 

Overall I feel like the game is awesome, filled a void that has been missing in the gaming industry for decades.. If you're a hardcore grind-fest MMO type of guy.. This game is what we've been missing. I can't speak much on the PVP, since I've stuck to a PVE server this whole time. But -- I do plan on transfering to a PVP server after release -- with some friends. That is another cool aspect to the game .. your character isn't stuck to one server. You can transfer your character to any other server within your region. You can even establish your guild across servers, and make a base in any of them. 

There are a lot of CONS though. Most are ones easily ignored, some probably worse depending on PVP/PVE servers.
 
1. Translation. It's terrible. It's not just the wording, it's the formatting as well. In some cases there is valuable information cut off the screen, because it fit in Chinese, but didn't fit in English. So in those cases you have to switch to Chinese just to see a number you needed. Not only is the translation still needing major polishing (which I suspect they may do after the 1.0 release), there are too many instances where things are referred to as different names, depending on which screen you're looking at. A particular attribute could be called "ABC" in one page, and then called "ZYX" in another page. 

2. Server regions aren't locked. Meaning EU, Chinese, NA can all join whatever region they want. And the Chinese players take major advantage of this. The map contains areas that can be 'claimed' by your guild marker, particularly farms. And it's also advantageous to build near mines. 75% of the best spots to build your base have already been claimed by Chinese players. And once it's claimed, very unlikely they'll ever leave as you can prevent your base from decaying for 2 weeks. Major problem on PVE servers. On PVP servers -- technically you could raid their base and try and claim the land. But ... again .. since it's not region locked Chinese guilds usually established dominance on every server. So if you're playing PVP .. probably want to avoid messing with Chinese guilds. If you're playing PVE, you don't have much to worry about Chinese guilds (other than losing out on prime building areas). The game is also set up so that guilds can become "magistrates" or in other words "King" of the server. In that case they can receive taxes on all players in that server. Chinese guilds usually hold that title in every server. This game would be a ton better with region locking. 

3. Combat, it's almost there. But still feels very clunky. You can play with 4-direction combat, or 8-direction. I will say 8 direction is best, and the hit boxes are actually very well-done for direction based melee combat. Shields are broken. Literally useless, only time you actually block is if you continuously walk backwards and prevent NPCs/players from getting face-to-face with you. Once they are directly in front of you, their attacks just clip through the shield. Parrying works very well, but it's extremely difficult, as you need to parry the direction of the swing. Often times hits just don't register, although the animation/voice registers. Certain animals are still very broken in terms of pathing .. especially bears. They just seem like they're whacked out on pure Colombian snow. Movements are spazzy, they randomly go from normal pace to lightning pace.. From what I've read -- PVP is mount/polearm only. Two-hander is backup when on foot. Supposedly you can just 1 shot anything with horse/polearm. Bows/crossbows are pretty much useless at end-game levels of PVP. One handed is okay, it's fast and you can almost stunlock. But two-handers do much more damage, much more capable of AOE, and they have a special talent suited for PVP -- heal upon killing an enemy. All in all, the combat is very similar to Mount&Blade .. just a bit less polished. 

4. Music. What music. Seriously, with 600 hours of game play, I've probably heard about 1 hours worth of music. Very quiet, mind-numbingly quiet. Great for watching videos on the other monitor though. 

5. I haven't looked much into it, but it looks like ever since the lawsuit and they had to privately sell the game -- they've adopted micro transactions. Most of them seem cosmetic only. But some of them seem eerily pay-to-win with resources being purchasable. Extremely lame. Hopefully they smarten up and get rid of that. 

6. The game has virtually no helpful content online. What's out there, only really covers like 20% of the game. Most of the videos, articles, posts you see about this game just cover early level stuff. The other 80% of the game, you're a pioneer and learning things for yourself. This isn't directly a con, because some might appreciate that aspect. But if you've got a specific question about something .. chances are you aren't finding that answer. 

All in all -- amazing game. MASSIVE potential. It's currently already very much a full game, with enough polishing to be enjoyed for a long time. But if they truly focus on optimizing the game -- and not going down the silly road of over-stuffing it with new features.. they have the opportunity to create a new longstanding classic in the hardcore MMO genre.

159258761.review:
SP only review:

Damn the thumbs up/down system -  MoE is in the middle, so I went with thumb down as they seem to get read more often ;)

In short, for €35, MoE is "undercooked" despite the fact that (or perhaps because) the Steam release was put on hiatus for 2+ years for legal reasons. Having said that, a game needing work is, to a large degree, to be expected for EA games (although MoE now sells as version 1.0!). While MoE is in better condition than say Conan Exiles (being a similar game) was when the latter first released, MoE still has some really awful rough edges that can make it a pretty painful experience to play. 

First off, the game is very doable in SP and can provide a good SP experience, even with the issues I discuss below. I have not been everywhere in game and certainly not done all there is to do, but after 40+hours I have gotten into what I think is mid-game (level 40 character, iron armour/weapons, base, followers, horses etc) and have had some fun doing it - but there has been a lot of expletives and a lot of 'taking the Lord's name in vain' along the way - sometimes a combination of those two things at once.

Some positives first as there are PLENTY - for example, there's a mod workshop, the game world looks great, there's a great array of assets (buildings, trees, grasses, rocks etc), there is a lot to do (build, combat, explore, complex farming, taming, cooking, medicine,training, upgrading everything, taking over existing settlements etc) so it holds your interest and there's seemingly always more to discover and try out. Skills (swordsmanship, lumbering, mining etc) are learned by doing while benches, build sets (which also look great) and weapon/armour types etc are accessed by spending points gained with character level rises - which is a great combo. The map is big and feels it, there's a good variety in the mobs and how they wander around (not always the same animal following the same path when you go into an area, so like ARK), the follower system is not just copy-paste from Conan (hard to understand all that is going on here - including bench/settlement automation via thralls -  but it seems a fresh take on the idea), the workbenches, weapons and armour etc all look fantastic and the skins available for them only add to this being an impressive aspect. The character creator is solid if not amazing, the tattoos add a nuance if that's your thing (although almost constantly hidden by your armour, of course) and, after 40+ hrs, I have had zero freezes, crashes or error message pop-ups. There's more good, but this is already a long read so I won't detail it all. 
 
With the bad, where to start? Some stuff is a bit meh and/or somewhat annoying (the UI/UX is pretty busy and fairly invasive for example - I can't tell my horse's 'quality' because the classification is obscured by other UI elements), however, other things just drove me nuts. - like the lack of info. There is a lot going on in this game and the learning curve is pretty steep, however, the instructions are limited at best, A LOT is simply not explained at all, even when checking online (what does 'Comprehension' trait do exactly?) and the limited instructions the game does provide is in such awful English they make no sense. This is an all pervasive problem as, adjusting server settings is possible (thumbs up, great but many settings don't actually change things in game and changes you make don't save from session to session meaning they need to be redone each login) but what are "Compulsory Creep Kill", "Switch of the Money Tree", "Player's Collect Damage Multiplier" (this is in the 'Collection' settings, not combat, so..?) and "Sidebar Durability Loss on Battlefield"?. Should the "Hunger Decrease Multiplier" go up or down to reduce how much I eat per day (FYI, it has to go down) and in the 'Damage Settings' the "Unused Parameter" is set to 1.0 by default - is that a good thing, is it even a parameter given it is apparently unused? Parts of the UI are still just in Chinese.

The building system is as ordinary as they were 20 years ago - want an overhanging roof/awning, roof pieces only angle up from walls not down (snap points only at the bottom of them it seems), foundations don't snap to ceilings, no height adjuster for foundations, no parts overlap (can't even place walls on a foundation after stairs are placed on that foundation) - but roof pieces clip through walls into 2nd storey rooms. Roofs don't snap to ceilings or each other, only walls. Terrain clipping that prevents building is brutal (only try to build on super flat land), stacked stairs that 'zig-zag' back on themselves (hard to explain but a neat design) don't allow a standard sized character to go up them unless you crouch. Placement is also EXTREMELY twitchy: select a piece you want to build, on screen it drops into the space you want it to be in, press click and it builds at 90 or 180 degrees to what was shown, again and again and again. You can place a pillar on the corner of a foundation then add a wall to the foundation edge, but you can't place the wall then the pillar - this 'sequential placing' happens with roof pieces as well. Corner roofs have no snap points that allow you to attach another roof to them. You get the idea.

There are certain indestructible bushes that can't be harvest or removed in any way that will clip into your base if you build on them.

Work benches can't be freely rotated before placement - you have to place them facing you, leading to all sorts of problems in tight spaces or placing them on the edges of raised floors/foundations where your character drops off the edge before getting the bench in place. Some benches require (relatively) huge amounts of empty space around them to place - and some already occupy an area of 2x2 foundations.

There is no pick up or moving anything - place a cheap nasty vase in the wrong spot- it's there to stay, misplace a top-tier foundation, it's there to stay, bench too far from the wall - demolish with 50% resource refund and re-craft is your only option.

Then there is combat...OMG - it's not just a button mashing fest, and that's a good thing right? However, at level 42, with iron armour/weapons and a reasonable sword skill level (300+?), I had my ass comprehensively handed to me by a level 16 bandit captain who shrugged off 30-40 hits from my sword before providing me with the mercy killing I probably thoroughly deserved - ok, I'm not the world's greatest swordsman but a level 16 guy using gear that was visually lower tier than mine should not walk away from a fight with a character 3 times his level. Oh, did I mention NPC's using missile weapons NEVER miss, literally, hit rate is set to 100% unless the shot is blocked by a rock, building etc. On the whole, combat is slow (the bandit above took probably 2-3 minutes to kill me), pretty painful, quite technical (8 options for directional attacks which you need to master - like the bandits already have) and a bit janky as both the animations and hit boxes seemed to me to be a little off. Damage values also cannot be effectively varied - sure you can pump up/down the damage you do with a blade....but it's server-wide so all the NPCs get the same buff/debuff. My doctor has told me not to discuss the mounted combat....it's enough to say only use a polearm as a weapon and...urghhh...I have no words.

There is more but suffice to say there are issues both great and small - hopefully these get fixes and some TLC over time, including optimisation - I have a GTX 1080Ti with 16GB and an i7-8700 and get wildly fluctuating FPS between 10-60 on medium settings, 15 FPS on high settings.

In short, it's not a bad game, there's a lot here to like and if the devs persist building on what they have this will be another game like Conan/ARK that I will sink 1000s of hrs into, but if you jump in now, be prepared for some SP frustration.

159985565.review:
I'm reviewing this from the standpoint of playing on a private, dedicated server, with friends.

Ark + Conan Exiles, genetically spliced with a bit of Mount and Blade. Crafting and building systems immediately familiar to anyone who has played Ark or Conan - but with much more added depth. We're ~40 hours in and still have only scratched the surface.

I love the neat details - like the deep horse taming/raising system. Being able to mount a wagon to your horse, then tell your troops to ride in the wagon, then go out harvesting knowing your wagon has plenty of space for your harvest - and you have your men with you if you need them - stuff like that.

Some may find the complexity of the game overwhelming - but I personally find it refreshing, for an Ark/Conan-style game.

There is some jank, for sure - combat can feel a little 'disconnected' at times - other times it feels great. Translation issues make figuring out some things trial and error - but we haven't yet run in to anything that was completely indecipherable.

Overall, if you like survival/craft/building games - enjoy complexity - and don't mind having to figure some things out for yourself, or the hard way - I say give it a try. I can't speak for the official server experience - but it does offer things a single dedicated server does not.

Do not trust the negative comments, this game is like Conan, Ark & Mount & Blade had a weird baby, with the best of all 3.  

The companions are top tier.  They're not OP solo-everything like Conan, but they're smart as heck (now I haven't played M&B but friends are saying the combat and troop commands are similar) but the AI is a major improvement over Conan & ARK, with "whistle for horse to come" only getting stuck on very few/rare "camps" or "raider tents" and such, but they'll navigate a ridgeline to come to you, not just B-line into a ravine and die like you'd see in ARK (if it had fall damage, which MOE does).

I can go on and on but this game does NOT get the credit it deserves.

Are there translation issues?  Yea, kinda, suuuuper minor.
Are there server issues?  Yea, kinda, just rent or host your own with friends. (or play solo with higher rates)
Are there UI issues?  No, not really.  The UI is extremely intuitive given the vastness of the game, it didn't take much at all to pickup.  Lots of shortcut commands (similar to ARK, same engine) and layout is aces once you learn what everything is.
What else are people complaining about?  I think it was mostly UI/Lag, and the company is already working on improving the official servers.

This game 100% supports PvE with plenty of content. 

Insanely good progression, we're on a vanilla rates server and it feels fantastic.

Log in and your horse is gone?  mia?  nothing?  most games; that's it, curtains.  MoE?  Check the log, it'll say HOW and WHERE and WHEN it died. (or just look at the map if it's alive and you'll see markers for all your warriors & mounts)

So many endless problems from other games are solved in MoE, it's insane.  Thousands of hours in ARK/Conan-style games and this is by FAR The king of the crop.

Cons?  
-structure placement is like vanilla ARK, it doesn't like "placing" in the environment/ground/terrain.  So you gotta be cheeky if you're OCD on how things look.
-server running, setting up, editing, modifying, configuring; it's all a bit of a pain.  Lots of communities working together to try to get things working, again, much like Vanilla ARK.  So give this game time to grow, get some modders to give us a S+ style building, or the company to give us a CVAR.  

You're missing out if you're not giving this game a good shot, especially if you're already a fan of the genre.

163115049.review:
I've spent the past few years diving deep into open-world survival games, usually teaming up with friends. Out of all the games we've tackled recently, Myth of Empires stands out—and not in a good way. It's probably the worst. I've come across single-developer projects that are more polished than this. Writing a review is a bit tricky because pointing out the glaring flaws might make me look like just another hater. But I really did try to give it a chance, even with my already low expectations based on other reviews.

It only takes about 60 seconds of enduring the low-quality "motion blur" as you move through the game world to start questioning why someone decided it may be a good idea to forcefully worsen your visual experience. Turn it off, and things seem better—until you start gathering materials and are forced to excuse the questionable character animations. You might hope these are merely cosmetic issues, but alas, it only gets worse.

The game seems purposefully designed to be sluggish. You're met with slow character movements, slow (and borderline unplayable) combat, unnecessary crafting countdowns and more. It feels like the game is stealing moments of your life. The animations are primitive and unnatural, seemingly ripped straight from games that are 30 years old. As for the game’s UI, it's a disaster (and let’s not even get started on the poor translations and the UI's failure to adapt to the resulting texts).

I spend some time reading positive reviews just to understand why there are any. Basically any other "Open World Survival Game" on Steam would be "overwhelming positive" compared to this. Try Conan Exiles, Enshrouded, The Planet Crafter, Soulmask and many others ...

Money wasted, moving on ...

Note: While others have mentioned a few innovations, enduring even the basic mechanics of this game makes it a tragic setting for such potential breakthroughs. I just hope they find a way into professional productions.

so i have 100 hours played now and what i am finding is :

first and most important, 

THE SERVERS:
how the servers are implemented is very very poor. pings of over 400 are extremely common. we have been told in discord that servers are located at there stated location. NA are in NA, EU are in EU and so on. this has been revealed by many running trace routes that all data at some point goes to Singapore and servers are in fact not at there stated locations. with this in mind there seems to be a data dump going back to Singapore every few minutes or so that cause game to freeze briefly followed by rubber banding for a further 5-15 second.

SERVERS PART 2: 
there are servers that are region locked with a flimsy system at best to try and stop the Chinese hordes from over running pretty much every server they get into. these regions are supposed to be for the likes of NA and EU players who don't want to have to deal with them. sadly this system is failing and the Chinese have infiltrated just about every server locking some of them down to 1 guild per server because every one else has sadly been raided or simply quit.

THE GRIND:
the grind for non paying casual players is substantial. in 100 hours i have managed to get to level 35 with help from the AFK system. i believe an option to buy experience has just been added to level up faster but not grant any special weapons or tools that give an advantage if you choose to shorten the grind.

CRAFTING:
the crafting system is huge and quite in depth and fun to work with. gives you many options for stuff to be built. like structures, lots of weapons and armours and much more.

TAMING:
taming is fun when done manually, build a pen and trap a horse and break it by riding it. some higher level horses can take some time but worth it. animals can also be put in stables to be tamed with AI assist if you don't want to ride them.

GRAPHICS:
the graphics look quite good in most aspects and pleasing to the eye, there is some locations you look out and think that looks impressive. then there is under the water that leaves much to be desired.

in conclusion i am not going to recommend this game at this time due to the horrible server setup they have in place producing pings of 300ms - 400ms for the majority of people playing and the very very flimsy region lock that has failed so many looking to enjoy the game. 

if in the future they do fix the server locations and region lock then this game would most defiantly be worth playing.

159037802.review:
A survival building game with troop recruiting set in a Three Kingdoms era theme? This is my kinda game.
Besides that there is a lot of really nice quality of life features that you don't see in other games like this.
  
For instance if you have the help menu open showing some of the basic controls to help you remember it'll highlight when you are using the button. Or when you are mounted with your troops you can see a little white dot showing you which inventory you want to target between the horse and rider to make it real easy.

I see a lot of people gripe about the UI. It's fine but it has a lot of information but I like that. The quest log can overlap the UI space that shows what you pick up and drop but it's no big deal since you can just untrack the ones in the way.

The skill system is something I like a lot as well where you level up the skills as you use them, but you can put points into them specifically to be able to gain XP in those fields faster.

Plus it's easy to play solo or I'm assuming with friends since it has a Steam connection setting when creating a game. Not to mention it lets you host a server and I'm pretty sure you don't have to rent one which is huge. Also there's public lobbies and private ones to try if you want to get a PvP experience.

You can buy skins for various items but they aren't stat increasing or anything.

Gripes:

The building is specific on how it wants to be built so you have to be careful what direction a wall is facing which is annoying. It might take some fighting to make a fairly simple building but I was able to do what I was trying.

162508761.review:
Overall, I liked about 25% of this game, and disliked 75%. 

[b]PROS:[/b] 

- Addictive
- Lots of idle play, so it's nice if you have a lot going on IRL
- The storage-chest-naming system is actually good!

[b]CONS:[/b]

- Very buggy (I'm being generous here)
- Huge frame rate problems if you have a large 40+ member guild fortress
- In relation to the previous bullet—small guilds on PVE servers will find XP unbearably slow
- ENORMOUS amount of grinding time to max out skills (I have 414 hours logged, and I haven't come close to maxing a single skill yet, and there are many skills)
- PVP Combat is worse than Gloria Victis (lots of teleporting due to server instability, and functionally, the combat is poorly designed)
- NPCs block almost all of your attacks, so you're forced to game the system by constantly walking backwards and aiming for their feet (feels like cheese every encounter)
- More rubber-banding than any other online multiplayer game I've played to date
- Copper coins take a LOT of farming time if you don't dish out the real cash to buy them (this game is almost pay to win, but just barely isn't—it's definitely on the line)
- The game's ambitious, large-scale battles aren't supported by good technical execution (it simply doesn't do well what it set out to do)
- The UI is confusing, and inconsistent from menu to menu, and often punishing if you misunderstand or misclick
- The chat UI often doesn't automatically scroll down when new messages come in, and text wraps mid word
- The game is not small-guild (or solo) friendly, even a little

I somewhat enjoyed the suffering this game inflicted, and yet I wouldn't recommend someone else experience that same suffering.

I can understand 2+ tier difference, but where I play my guild has the 2nd best tier equipment (just started on the 1st) and we can easily see the difference.

2) Need to get higher skill or you will be dragged to the ground.  Example:  I'm almost 750 skill in heavy armor, polearm, and 750 physique.  If a player with over 750 (not quite 900 yet) hits me the damage they will do is significant.  Combine that with 1 level higher tier equipment... you get the point.

3) The server ping currently is unbearable.  If you get under 200 ping that is a blessing.  Normal ping sits around 300 or higher.  I don't know where the servers are located, but the server I play on is NA (North American) and I live in Florida.  I play using a Fiber Optic internet with 100up/100down speed.  Everything is working great.  So the issue isn't on my side.

4) When PvP involves more than 5 vs 5... it can get very laggy and rubber band lag quickly.  We had a siege the other day and between putting down defensive structures and players in the field... the lag made it very difficult to fight because of all the PING issues and rubber banding.

5) Extremely time consuming.  This is NOT for the casual gamer if you are on the live multiplayer servers.

IF they can fix this terrible PING and rubber banding it would be helpful.  The other flaws I don't know if they can resolve, but I guess it is possible if they even out the advantages of having 1 tier versus another in equipment.

160754028.review:
One if the best Online Survival Games around. It's not for everyone. To many people get beat, loose their stuff and rage quit because they were to attached to their stuff in-game. I see it over and over, then they come on Steam to give the game a bad review. You need a good group of people to work with. It doesn't have to be a big group. 2 or 3 friends and you can have a blast in this game. There are so many things you can do.

Do you like Farming? Cool, pick up a hoe and start tilling a farm plot. The resources you acquire from it helps in the production of food, medicine and even weapon and armor crafting. So even if you are not a pvper your contribution to a clan's success is huge! Just please, don't try to go at it alone out there. You will end up back here giving a bad review on this game because some clan big or small rolled through your wooden base and took all your sh!t. All before you can truly explore the beautiful land ahead of you and everything it has to offer. 

Proficiency points is key for personal progression. If you are make it up the levels and decide to jump on a horse with a polearm to try your had at pvp but haven't worked on your armor, polearm, riding and physique proficiency's, you are probably in for a rude awakening during your encounters and will end up dead. You have 2 choices from there, either start your proficiency grinds to improve your abilities or rage quit, come onto Steam and complain how that 3 man clan was a chinese zerg that raided you in your sleep and how they exploited to kill you.

This game also has other fun things to do other than the open world, you can try your had at prefectures. Win or lose, the longer you last the more merits you earn to spend on a type of ore to make better weapons and armor. Want to learn or get a better understand of how to raid? Do a few Siege Battles to both better prepare you and also earn merits you can use to buy important things in the guild shop. Heck, do the jousting event against other people to get a feel of where you stand with both your skills and build vs players.

All and all, this game is put together very well for an online survival game. Does it have it's cons? Yes, Server stability could be improved, lag spiking from time to time that effects both official and unofficial servers. One of the Iron mines on the new map is glitch as F%$# and will have you floating if you step in the wrong spot. Also, exploits have been found. The devs have been pretty good on patching those up though my clan found one last night that could break raiding. We have sent that one straight to the devs so they can fix it asap. My clan and I are doing our part to help make this game even better. Is it a perfect game, no. But it really is a fun game with beautiful ascetics and great gameplay.

So in closing I will recommend this game to everyone but with some cautions:

DO NOT PLAY ALONE. Join a clan or get a few friends to play with you and start your own clan.

THIS GAME IS NOT INTENDED FOR KARENS. If you have a tendency of rage quitting after a death or 2 please don't bother buying this game. I really don't want to read your Karen a$$ $hit in the reviews later.

Play unofficial servers if you don't like the grind of official servers. Most server owners tend to adjust settings to the type of server they wish to have. Everything from PvP/PvE, times 4, 5, 10 xp and even modded servers.

Most importantly, have fun!

I will open by saying this is probably my new main game for a while. But that doesn’t mean it is perfect. 

I don’t know why, but even though the game feels great to play, videos of it definitely look janky when I watch them. For some reason it just plays better than it looks when you watch a 2 year old video on YouTube. 

Also, the ui can be a bit obnoxious and make it hard to understand the surprisingly nuanced and honestly incredibly well designed game systems which can be annoying, but the pay off on how cool some of the stuff is, is well worth it. Finally the combat is incredibly fun (think a hybrid between M&B Banner lord and Last Oasis), as a noob you may just get spammed down, but at even mid skill level it is obvious that positioning, timing, and parrying are definitely big factors. Finally the game just feels good to play. It’s just fun.

All that being said, BE WARNED THIS GAME IS NOT Solo Friendly you NEED a group/guild, furthermore the game includes a system similar to Albion of EVE where players can buy premium currency with real cash and then trade it to other players for in game money, so if that leaves a bad taste in your mouth, don’t buy this game. If you can stomach pay for convenience/slight advantage mechanics like Plex in EVE or Gold in Albion then check out this game! 

11/10 would play with friends and die to tigers again!

160447928.review:
Pros:
Great building mechanics. Has an in depth progression system with many paths to choose. The tame breeding system is exemplary with huge payoffs for specializing in taming, breeding, and running your own horse mill. The game makes use of a quest based tutorial system which helps and guides the player through the many aspects of the game. There are dailies and weeklies to help gauge your progress which I believe aids the game immensely. 

The game also makes use of an interconnected auction house between all the servers in your cluster. This allows you to specialize in one area and sell your business for in game currency. In game currency can be used to buy 'anything' on the market so you don't have to specialize in everything to gear up and play the game.

Cons:
Your capacity and ability to PvP/combat in this game is gated by an extreme grind which requires an exploit to progress to the level to remain competitive. Whether this is oversight by the developers or quietly intended by them it is a huge game killer. The damage you deal and the health/resistances you have is tied directly to what's called your "proficiency". Proficiency is gained by hitting enemies with the weapon of your choice to increase that proficiency. More proficiency = more damage overall. This creates a massive divide in player capability on the battlefield.

Competitive players and groups increase this proficiency by exploiting the thrall (NPC Slave) taming system and herding foxes into a 2x1 hut. I'm not going to disclose how this is done but it is a ridiculous exploit which requires a ton of time and menial mouse clicking/and or macro autoclicking (not consuming the content of the game, like doing treasure maps, clearing camps/bases, etc). If you're not performing this exploit you're going to essentially be unable to participate in any PvP or high tier combat activities. The entire premise of proficiency gain in this game is regulated by this exploit which makes the game not very fun; which is a shame because the game has good bones.

An addition to this problem is the fact that you have to keep the game running in the background of your PC to gain what's called 'idle proficiency', which acts as a booster to proficiency gain overall. It's just my opinion but I find having to keep the game open to gain idle proficiency ridiculous and I speculate this is used to pad gameplay hours for reviews such as these and maintain a healthy steamchart status.

Overall conclusion:
I wouldn't recommend this game to any players who don't enjoy grinding. Grind is the foundation of the game and if you don't enjoy it you won't enjoy the game at all. There are some great aspects of the game where you can log in to enjoy some relative simple tasks on PvE servers such as farming and horse taming but if you want to PvP in this game you're going to need to partake in numerous exploits to 'get ahead'. If your background is Rust you're not going to have a good time -- maybe more in line with hardcore Ark.
160447928.developer_response:
Hey Sturmtruppe,

We're sorry the game's negatives outweighed its positives for you. To answer one of the points you made, the idle training system has been implemented so that players can gain proficiency without taking up a spot on a server, and not to pad the game's stats. Nevertheless, your feedback has been well-received and I've forwarded it along to the devs. We'll keep putting work into the game, with the aim to make it an enjoyable experience for all players. Thank you!

Ever wanted a game where all progress is marked by how efficiently you can hold down left click for hours on end? Well then this here is the game for you. Every single part of this game feels as though it was built to be the most soul crushing grind imaginable. As an example, say you're starting with a big name group. This group is well established and has top tier gear ready for you. There's a problem however, and its that you aren't efficient in armor or weapons. If you try to use this gear, you'll receive a -%75 debuff to damage and armor. Now how do you fix this? Simple, just hit and get hit by enemies for actual weeks as you slowly grind up your stats to be decent.

But lets say you're not down with that. You've played dark souls and this game has a complex blocking system so surely you can still use the gear if you're a good enough player. Well, here's the kicker. If you're too low level, enemies can just ignore any blocks you do with a sword or shield.

This isn't a "game" as to call it as such would be an insult to gaming as a medium. It is a soulless $40 hamster wheel meant to rob you of as much of your time as humanly possible. And they didn't even both to do a full translation of the game to english. Avoid this at all costs if you have any respect for you and your time.

159194214.review:
The idea of a survival crafting sandbox mixed with MMO elements is fantastic, especially with the player character, npcs, and buildings being inspired by real world history. That being said, there is one major flaw that is keeping me from investing in this game. Admittedly, it's not a problem that would affect most players- but it is a simple fix that can help bring in some players. 

Within the options menu, you can change almost every keybind except for the interact key. Now I'm a weirdo and play on ESDF rather than WASD, and the default interact key is E. Because of this, every time I move I interact with whatever is in front of me and it makes for an unenjoyable experience. Even for those who don't play on ESDF, having a changeable interact key would be a nice simple change for those who don't like E for interacting.

There are also some minor changes that I would like to see. As others have mentioned, the UI is pretty cluttered and there are some parts that are in Chinese despite having English translations on. Some of the text doesn't fit within its window, and it's kinda jarring to look at- especially with a price tag of $40. 

The tattoo and beard customizations are fantastic. You can place several tattoos wherever you wish on your body, and it's nice to have scruffier/thin beard options rather than the typical giant ball of fluff that most games have. Despite that, I'm surprised that there's a lack of changing eye color. Again I know for most people this won't matter- as you'll most likely cover your head in a helmet, but I think having a bit more customization options would allow for great roleplaying potential for players wanting to join an RP focused server.

Overall, I'm excited about future development of this game- as there's not anything like it on the market. I recommend this game if you're fine with the default controls and are looking for a survival crafting sandbox while also being able to team up/fight against other players on a bigger scale (though you can also play solo if you wish) + aren't too bothered by small details being off. But with me personally, I won't be playing this game until the keybind issue is resolved.

158938169.review:
Myth of Empires is legitimately the worst survival game I have ever played. The representation of Myth of Empires in promotional materials may create misleading expectations. The actual gameplay experience deviates significantly from the content showcased in the provided videos.

Myth of Empires faces challenges in providing an enjoyable experience due to its plethora of overly complicated menus and skill tree systems that seem to lack significant purpose. Furthermore, the user interface appears to be stuck in the early 2000s, presenting an unnecessarily cumbersome obstacle in terms of usability and navigation.Additionally, a significant drawback arises as substantial sections of the game lack proper translation into various languages, and essential tool tips that would elucidate the gameplay for the player are notably absent.

The game's animations could benefit from more depth, character, and a smoother overall feel. Currently, the gameplay feels somewhat cumbersome and fatiguing, particularly in combat situations. These issues could potentially hinder the overall gaming experience, especially in a PvP setting, making it less enjoyable.

The gameplay experience becomes quite demanding in this game. As you progress in your skills, one would expect tasks to become more manageable. However, the reality is that each advancement introduces a heightened level of difficulty to every process. Transitioning from stone to bone to bronze tools should logically signify an improvement, yet it leads to an overwhelming resource grind. This dynamic creates the sensation of navigating through the game as if on an endless treadmill with no clear destination.

In essence, Myth of Empires attempted to emulate the success of titles like Ark: Survival Evolved and Conan Exiles. Unfortunately, it falls significantly short, failing to capture even half the essence of the gaming experience offered by its inspirational sources. Myth of Empires, positioned as a survival game, struggles to find its identity, often veering into the realm of an MMO. The overly complex systems within the game contribute to its lackluster appeal, leaving players with a sense of dissatisfaction and frustration.

I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone.

161796347.review:
Единственный, по моему мнению, плюс этой игры это глубокая многоуровневая прокачка персонажа и гильдии в остальном к сожалению это шлак. Графика так себе, для непредвзятого игрока сойдет.
В игре огромное количество станков с безумными пропорциями или очень маленькие или наоборот огромные. Пропорции и размеры станков это отдельная песня и не поддается никакой логике, они дико уродливые и примитивные, причем имеют невидимые текстуры и рядом ничего не поставить.
Продвинутые станки не заменяют простые, к примеру продвинутый оружейный станок не делает инструменты итд, а продвинутый дубильный не делает простую кожу и в итоге надо ставить два и даже три огромных станка одного типа, которые делают всего два типа кожи каждый. Вообщем это все кривое полностью, переставлять станки нельзя, только ломать, ресурсов возвращают мало, а крафтятся они до полутора часов реального времени.
Стройка тоже кривая и очень примитивная, больше тут и сказать нечего.
Анимации кривые, персонаж еле ползает, а в тяжелой броне еще и штраф накидывают. Боевка вообще пример рукожопости. Переключение между оружием и инструментами в быстром доступе работает через раз и ооочень медленно. 
Оружия мало, арбалет использовать невозможно, он заряжается издевательски долго и по несколько раз, если персонаж шевельнется, лук стреляет криво. Брони тоже очень мало, на каждом тире 2-3 сета, есть еще альтернативная броня, но открыть ее можно только  в результате бесконечного однообразного фарма одних и тех же локаций. 
Инструменты всего 3 тира, самый высокий железо, хотя после железа еще есть 2 тира, черный металл и метеоритный металл, но инструментов таких нет и в итоге надо 20+ раз ударить железным молотком руду высокого тира чтобы разбить, зачем этот мазохизм? 
Игра заставляет много играть в афк, иначе невозможно прокачать таланты. К примеру многие таланты качаются только если персонаж работает на станке, а учитывая что крафт ооочень медленный, то чтобы скрафтить  меч, щит и лук надо полчаса стоять за станком и тупо смотреть на таймер. Можно скрафтить и без персонажа но при этом нет прокачки и характеристики оружия будут отстойные. И так во всем, надо бесконечно прокачивать в афк различные таланты иначе прогресса не будет. Ходят слухи что китайские друзья таким образом майнят крипту и это вполне вероятно поскольку нормальной игровой прокачки тут очень мало. То есть многие и многие часы ты вынужден играть при этом не играя, а заниматься чем то другим при запущенной игре, поскольку персонаж привязан к станку чтобы прокачать таланты и без этого никак.На высоких уровнях это гавно превращается в бесконечный однообразный фарм и гринд. Мир очень примитивный, никакого разнообразия нет, все миссии и так называемые данжи очень скучные и однообразные. 
По сути сделана большая глубокая система прокачки, а все вокруг слепили как попало с одной целью заставить чтобы игра была запущена 24 часа в сутки для тупого фарма и гринда. 
Уровень локализации запредельно низкий и кривой и сделана что называется на от...ись она не только не точная, но во многих местах полностью ошибочная или бессмысленная,например лен называется пшеницей итд итп, надо постоянно переключаться на английский  чтобы понять что то. Разрабы просто наплевали на русский язык. 
Ну и наконец что касается оптимизации то ее тут нет совсем. На сервере с онлайном 20+ постоянно проблемы с пингом, лагами, телепортами итд и хотя игре больше 2 лет, ничего не меняется. 
Вся игра настроена на то чтобы маниакально затянуть все что возможно, это явно было целью и проходит красной линией.  Рекомендовать это полностью кривое произведение никак не получается, после 300 часов уже тошнит от этой игры, только удалить полностью и забыть.

I bear a lot of good will towards this studio who broke away from Snail Games then got sued over re-using code they'd wrote before for Snail Games which significantly hampered development. Official servers languished in a horrible lag-fest of server performance for years while Angela Game Studio scaled down everything to stay afloat. After the lawsuit settled they officially launched out of early access and it's been a month since.

Initially server performance was better than before launch and we got a new map to play on which is objectively better than the melted candle wax map we had before. However since then server performance has been steadily declining, with many theories of why, ranging from the feasible to the bigoted conspirational as usual. 
Fact are, after so many years and an official release the game is still sub par to what it ought to be and missing so many quality of Life features that every other game in the genre using the same engine does sport that I can't in all honestly recommend this game.
Much as I would want to. It goes on the pile of "Coulda Shoulda Woulda" where it'll languish next to its Snail Games predecessor Dark and Light and other Snail Game pukefest Ark Survival Ascended.

Title: "Myth of Empires: A Thrilling Adventure with Room to Grow"

Rating: 4.4 out of 5 stars

Embark on a thrilling journey through the realms of "Myth of Empires," where strategic building, resource collection, and epic battles await at every turn.

One of the standout features of "Myth of Empires" is its diverse gameplay mechanics. I've found immense enjoyment in constructing and expanding my empire, while also relishing the excitement of engaging in combat and gathering valuable resources. Additionally, the ability to team up with friends in a guild adds a layer of camaraderie and shared adventure that enhances the overall experience.

While my exploration of the player-versus-player (PvP) aspect awaits, I anticipate diving into it soon. However, one aspect I hope to see improved is the management of server regions and guild sizes. Limiting the influence of other regions on servers and imposing restrictions on guild sizes could help prevent large groups from dominating the game's landscape.

Overall, "Myth of Empires" earns a solid 4.4 out of 5 stars from me. It's a fantastic game to enjoy with friends, offering an accessible experience that doesn't overwhelm newcomers. As the developers continue to roll out updates and improvements, I look forward to revising my review and witnessing the game's evolution. Whether you're seeking adventure, camaraderie, or strategic challenges, "Myth of Empires" delivers an engaging experience that's well worth exploring.

103105421.review:
hmmmm. So I've spent 16 hours in the game, give or take, read the manual for it, and I've done enough content to comment on this a bit from a huge survival genre fan standpoint, but also can comment from a more technical standpoint as i've worked in the game development field as well.

This game is pretty good. that is your TL:DR of it. If you enter this to compare it to conan exiles, RUST, mount and blade, conquerors blade, ARK, Life Is Feudal, etc. then you are already setting yourself up for disappointment.

This game is very early access. Yes, it has a huge amount of content, sandbox building, skill trees, in depth grouping, guilds, city government type stuff, and other really unique features I was surprised to see. But some of the more core game mechanics need polishing. The combat is very rough around the edges as they focus on 2 different combat styles. This is coming from someone using their classic combat mode, I will be switching next time im on the other combat mode.

Also, everyone is really early level. My current official server, the top is lv 28 before penalties, And i've been putting a lot of time into the game as well, but I am no where near top level or high level crafting. I don't even know where to get Iron yet.

The PVP i cannot even comment on because I am on an official server which is PVE currently, but you can take your character to other servers (Counties).

Translation needs work, combat needs work, some animations need work, the building system needs a few adjustments but it works.

Again, its not a terrible game, It is pretty, its fun if you are into these sorts of games, and I cannot wait to start getting into diplomacy, seeing how transactions and trades work out, see a huge siege battle or huge armies marching by.

Again, if you come into this game comparing it to others, you will start off having a bad time. Every game everyone is comparing this too all started in this state and crawled out of their bad reviews slowly. Giant survival games like this take a lot of polishing before they end up great. Some dont even make it to the great part.

The state of this game and early access, and if you like survival type games? I can recommend. It is constantly being updated, bugs are getting squished, you can tell by the systems in place that the developers like what they are working on, its a good game. Will it get better? in time of course. They seem to be listening to the playerbase / early access buyers, so yeah, I can recommend. Needs work though, but its playable and enjoyable. Also, go start in the riverlands or the mountains, its beautiful out there.

I would ignore the low hour count reviews. Not disregarding their opinion, but the game does not really open up till around lv 20. A lot of today's pc gamer's demand a lot of instant satisfaction and do not realize this is a slow burn game like ARK or conan. It takes time to get to where you need to be, but each tier is rewarding and does not feel grindy.....yet. time will tell though.

current state? 7/10

Its not bad, but needs work.

105007308.review:
While the game looks promising, at the current point I cannot really recommend it.

Let's first bring up some of the positive things:

.) The world looks gorgeous. Nothing wrong there. The map is beautiful, the characters creation has lots of options and the items and gear look for the most part very well done.
.) Controlling horses feels interesting. They are not easy to control but it gives the game a good feeling. Horses don't just stop on the spot as if hitting some brakes. They also don't turn around on the spot. The game does this very well.
.) Crafting has depth and is rather interesting. The modular house building is well done.
.) The map is big! This is amazing to me. I like big maps.
.) Animations are exceptional, especially for animals. How they move and act feels very natural and realistic.
.) Bugs are not very widespread, in this regard it is very solid for an early access title.

Then there are things, that some might like, that might still be improved on that I don't worry too much about, but that I personally don't enjoy in its current state:

.) Walking speed is what one might be used to from other survival open world games, nothing new there. Sprint speed however is extremely slow. One could argue about realism and all that, but in the end it's still a game. It's not fun feeling like a snail that has a sprinting speed only like 20-30% faster than walking speed.
.) NPCs don't do much when it comes to resource gathering. You only have a few and you cannot have your own little army. The amounts they gather is minuscule and really not worth mentioning in the overall scheme of things and its mostly a time sink. It doesn't help much when you have one of your NPCs gather ore for a dozen hours only for them to come back with a few hundred pieces. That's something you make yourself in 5-10 minutes. If you could have dozens of NPCs it might be different, but with such a low maximum, the effort just isn't worth it at all.
.) Many mechanics look like they offer a lot of depth, but they fall flat and are just made overly complicated to provide very simple things. This includes the whole nobility rank system, most of the taxes and benefit systems and most of the farming and food stuff.
.) There is no proper storage solution. You need raw materials and processed materials in all kinds of crafting stations, meaning you spread out your resources over multiple crafting stations all over the place instead of just being able to store your items somewhere and then using those stored items in some range directly to craft. The outcome is a lot of running around just dragging resources from one storage or crafting station to another.
.) Durability for tools is unbalanced to the extreme. You barely use some tools a few times before they already break. What's the point of having a horse with a cart when you can't even fill it up with a fully repaired tool?
.) Having torture devices as a means to make subordinates loyal to you is both questionable from a lore point of view, as well as very bad taste. There is no game reason to torture people. I'm neither squeamish or very worried about some cutscene where torture is implied, I'm also not worried if it makes sense in the game, for example if you have some enemy spy and want to get some information out of them. But for acquiring subordinates? That just makes no sense whatsoever. You don't torture people and then expect them to become your loyal followers. You might threathen them as a tyrant, you might torture others to intimidate them, but you don't just randomly torture someone and expect them to become loyal.

The game is still in early access and many of these things go along with balancing. The others are not bad enough to not give a recommendation. Theres a few things however that I dislike to a point where I didn't enjoy playing the game:

.) Mouse controls for the character feel horrible to the extreme. There is an insane delay of up to a second when turning around. It feels as bad as if you would be playing an FPS title with mouse acceleration turned up to the max. You cannot make precise movements, it feels clunky and unresponsive. Especially as this is a game that focuses on action combat, it makes the whole combat system garbage
.) You have no way to preview buildings that you place. You see a random light outline, that for the most part gives you no idea where the front entrance might be, how the building might look when placed. On top of that once placed, there is no time to move, turn or change it in any way, as such you can only destroy it and make a new one.
.) Combat balancing is so far off the charts that it makes fighting anything a bother. You can be level 30, with a full set of bronze armor and weapons, but a level 15 boar or wolf will still come close to killing you if they are alone, and they will massacre you if there are two. We're not talking about some legendary animal. It's your low-end run of the mill animals. That doesn't feel fun and makes no sense. A person in full leather armor with a sword not standing a chance against a wolf that cannot even bite through your armor is not very logical. Even from a game aspect, an overleveled, overgeared character shouldn't have any issues fighting a few animals if its boars or wolves. Heck even foxes kill you easily if there are 2 or 3 at the beginning.
.) There is nothing interesting to explore. The game currently feels like you run around pretty landscape, but at no point do you find anything "new" that is interesting or cool to see beyond appreciating the nice looks. The amount of enemies is rather small and they are all the same, other than perks there is no real reason to even explore in the first place and it feels like getting around is not only slow, even with a horse, but also pointless.

While Myth of Empires has definitely potential, and a first look is definitely interesting, especially the AI could be cool, it is not at the point currently, where I personally see it as fun to play. It feels too clunky, too unpolished when it comes to mechanics and combat and other than grinding stats and building a house, there is really not much to see when it comes to PvE. As for PvP .. with the combat controls this bad, it's not much fun either for me.

103963098.review:
The game is definitely a big step in the right direction for survival-multiplayer PvPvE games. I'm not trying to sell the game to anyone with my personal opinion. I will however point out features I appreciate.

Features that stand out to me:

Tutorial / Game Manual 
- Tutorial / Quest system to guide you from Beginning to End Game
- PDF extensive game manual 120 pages (access from your steam library / below achievements)

Sandbox - Open World - PvPvE  
64km map (approx. 25 square miles)
Official Servers PvP & PvE (Cross server transfer & travel system available)
Custom & Private Servers

Player activities
- PvP & PvE -- FULL LOOT
- Quests - Daily, Weekly, Tutorial/Guide, Guild.
- Siege systems for Players and NPCs
- NPC Camps, Cities, Forts
- "Dungeons" 
- Treasure hunting (unique items, recipes, rare items)
- Survival against elements Cold, Heat, Poison, NPCs, Hunger and player toxicity systems. 
- Animal taming / breeding
- Camp to Town to City to Empire management available 
- Extensive depth and character (and NPC) development
- Extensive crafting depth (at first glance the crafting may look basic, it is not)
- City / Resource point claiming systems
- Leaderboard system (tied to activity points)

Crafting System
- Basic crafting to advanced specialization crafting
- Advanced quality crafting system (skills & talents - colored crafting levels)
- Durability & Efficiency systems
- Tools/Weapons/Armor usages tied to skill specialization system (using an iron sword with 0 skill in one hand can hinder the weapon and penalize the user)

Building systems
- Building quality levels tied to skills & talents 
- No terraforming 
- Place and snap to building (un-snap is toggle)
- Buildings have durability and decay if unprotected
- Numerous crafting tier levels ie Wood, clay, etc.

Guild Systems
- Guild leveling
- Alliance systems
- Prestige systems
- Guild specific skill trees to benefit players / playstyles
- Guild specific tech trees for guild specific buildings

Player customization and depth (deeper than most RPGS)
- Nobility perk system (a long term character growth tree)
- Skill proficiency systems (respec & adjustable)
- Skill specializations
- Perk system (mid-late game)
- Numerous Skills & Talent trees
- Tactic skill system (skills from mid-late game activity)
- In-game achievement system tied to "minor" permanent character stat increases 
- Perk system tied to map exploration (you must find shrines hidden throughout the world to get perk points)

Human NPCS and Creature NPCs
- Tame / Breed creatures for materials
- Tame / Breed horses for riding, hauling, warfare 
- Recruit / capture / convert Human NPCs to become workers / warriors
- Human NPC stats are similar to player stats & growth
- Human NPCs can have strengths or weaknesses ( you could get some really rare & unique  NPCs)
- NPC Equipment system for Horses, Warriors, Workers, and AI-NPCs. (you can equip your warriors/workers, just as you can knock out and steal items from NPCs)
- Permadeath system (note: this system is forgiving and happens only after certain conditions are met. You can lose a horse or Warrior and revive them initially, repeat loses can  lead to a permadeath)

Auction house system
- Horse auction
- Warrior / Worker auction
- Item auction and more

PvP & PvE Official servers
- There is not a single shard or single map
- ALL Servers can cross travel between one another
- Single character only for all official servers

NPC Factions
- Low faction will result in KOS
- Low faction can result in NPCs raiding your base or attacking you in open world
- Faction applies to animals/creatures as well (over hunting boars can have negative outcomes for your person or guild)

103351214.review:
I wish I could give this game a neutral/"meh" recommendation. While Myth of Empires does some things really well, other times it has features that are so lackluster or just boring. Let me also preface this by saying I LOVE survival games, so I've played my fair share of this genre. I've only played this game for ~20 hours and have only played on official PVE as a solo. So with that in mind, my opinion is very much that of a solo player playing on the gather/xp multipliers which the devs intended. In terms of progression, I've been able to hit level 28, which I believe the cap is 50 or so (I think)? So I've been able to experience features such as building a large base, taming soldiers, horses, etc. So let me explain what the game does right first. 

+ The amount of content, for an early access title, is HUGE. There are tons of building pieces, crafting stations, weapons, armor, etc. to unlock. To give a good example of this, I think there are 4 or so tiers of building pieces in the game (Wood, Clay, Stone, Metal) To put this into perspective, Ark: Survival Evolved released with 2 tiers.
+ The map is also HUGE. I've only explored maybe a 1/5th of the map in my whole 20 hours. There are also different biomes to encounter as well. The biomes can range from swamp, mountains, plains, rain forest, etc. 
+ To add onto the map, there are a good amount of AI camps which you can go and try and kill or capture them. There are some friendly camps as well which allow you to peacefully recruit your "warriors" by giving them certain items (Ex. 18 bandages, 22 raw meat, coarse leather armor). 
+ The skill system is pretty runescape-esque and diverse. You can level up woodcutting, physique, riding, etc. Each of the categories comes with their own perks you can unlock as you level up. If you love grinding, then you'll love this. 
+ The guild system is pretty interesting and in depth as well. You can level up your guild by spending coins and activity points (You get these points just by playing) on buffs that apply to everyone in your guild. There are also certain guild buildings that can be unlocked and used by your guild. Trade posts, watch towers, territory marker, etc. 
+ Game performance is pretty decent. My rig isn't the greatest either and I can run it just fine on low-medium settings at 60 FPS.

Now that the good features in this game have been outlined, let's get into the bad of the game... and there are a lot of them. 

- Myth of Empires (On vanilla rates) is so FUCKING grindy for a solo player. Honestly, this is more a me problem than anything. This game was clearly meant to play in a large group. The guild system is HEAVILY favored towards large groups (duh). Those guild buffs can be super helpful too, if you don't have them you'll be playing at a disadvantage. So if you're thinking about playing this game solo, don't. 
- There isn't much PVE content in the game. Most of your time will be collecting resources to craft new items and buildings. This is just so BORING... there is a quest system to help alleviate that boredom, but even that is boring as fuck. You'll get quests to craft XYZ item or go collect XYZ resource. I haven't seen any main quests deviate from that method. There are some exceptions but even then they're boring.
- The movement feels so slow in this game, I understand it's trying to be realistic but come on... I can't even tell the difference between my character sprinting or walking. If you want to do any sort of traveling, a horse is pretty much required. Even then, the horse still feels slow. Now with breeding and training you can upgrade your horse, but holy fuck the early game feels so boring.
- The translation in this game is very... meh. I understand the development team is Chinese. But can't you hire a translator who's competent in translating Chinese to English? It feels like they pulled some random Joe off the street who spoke English, told him to translate, and called it good. Sometimes I get the general idea of what a certain item or feature is supposed to do, other times i'm at a loss for words. Some items just aren't translated at all either, the item or item description is still in Mandarin Chinese. 
- Building on my last point, this game is so confusing at times. The MOST important parts in the game are not explained whatsoever. Which I think for a survival game is fine! Trial and error can be super fun and rewarding when you finally figure out how something should work. But in this game, it's just frustrating. You want to know how to refresh your decay timer on your flag claim so your buildings don't decay? Nope, not explained! Well how do I make "donations" to the Imperial court, what about selling my items? Nope, fuck you not explaining! The amount of times I've seen people ask questions in in-game chat is astronomical (Most of which remained unanswered). This makes it so much worse with a language barrier and poor translation between the devs and players of this game.
-  The combat in this game is so bad, lol. MoE's combat system reminds me of a "For Honor" type system where you can attack and block at certain angles (up, right, left, down). But it feels so much worse, It feels so unresponsive at times. I cannot imagine how PvP is right now, and I don't even wanna know with how bad combat is right now. 
- This game is somewhat buggy too. Items and buildings not working correctly to the music cutting out and not playing at all making it dead silent. For an early access game released a couple days ago, that's to be expected honestly. More are bound to pop up so don't be surprised. 

I could go on but I think you get the general grasp of how this game is in its current state. There is so much to talk about that it would be impossibly long to cover everything. The foundation is definitely there, which I cannot say the same about other survival early access titles out there. I also haven't been able to explore everything there is to in this game, such as the government system. That would take waaay too long, and I honestly don't want to invest more time in this game until they polish it more. If you're desperate to play a Survival MMO game with the boys or just bored at of your mind, then I'd lightly recommend it. Otherwise, I would just wait a year,two, or even three before buying it. And who knows, maybe they'll just abandon the game and leave it half-finished. 

TL;DR.  Game has a lot of content, huge map to explore, and lots of features to learn and enjoy. But it feels too half-baked to warrant any sort recommendation. Wait a year, two, or even three before buying it.
